items.title: Game Day Cooking Grows as Home Kitchens Replace Stadium Lines
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Game day usually means long concession lines at the stadium, but it also means crowded kitchen counters at home as watch party hosts race to keep snacks coming. With 14.5 million viewers tuning in on streaming platforms alone, food becomes the unofficial co-star of the day. Shareable bites, scoopable dips and crowd-friendly desserts […] The post Game Day Cooking Grows as Home Kitchens Replace Stadium Lines appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
With 14.5 million viewers tuning in on streaming platforms alone, food has become a key part of the game day experience. 

Home kitchens are taking over game day food preparation, as high stadium concession prices push fans to recreate favorites at home for a fraction of the cost. Hosting at home allows for more control over ingredients, portions, and timing. Handheld and shareable foods like wings, sliders, dips, and desserts are staples of home game day spreads.

In 2025, the Sunday night NFL championship game averaged 127.7 million viewers, up 3% from 2024 and setting a new record. About 121.1 million Americans expect to host or attend a watch party this year, with total game day-related spending projected to hit $20.2 billion, or $94.77 per person.

The kitchen has become the "busiest spot in the house" on game day, as home cooks cater to viewing crowds without the hassle and high prices of stadium concessions. Experts note that this trend is driven less by necessity and more by the flexibility and control that home cooking provides over the stadium experience.

items.title: Chants, Competition, and Cattle: Auctioneers Eye World Championship
items.description: Since 1963, the Livestock Marketing Association (LMA) has been showcasing the talent of auctioneers from across North America through their qualifying events and the World Livestock Auctioneer Championship (WLAC). Each year, three qualifying events, open...
items.summary:
S., Mexico, and Canada. Each year, three qualifying events are held across the country, with the top 10 auctioneers from each event advancing to the WLAC. An additional 31st competitor also qualifies through an international event in Calgary.

During the qualifying events, each contestant sells 8 drafts of cattle, with the drafts varying based on the event location. Auctioneers are also interviewed by a panel of 5 judges chosen by the LMA. The LMA represents over 80% of livestock markets in the U.S. and is committed to upholding the live auction tradition to ensure local livestock markets remain viable.

The most recent qualifying events were held in Fredericksburg, Texas; Greenville, Tennessee; and Bowman, North Dakota. Some of the auctioneers who placed in the top 10 and qualified for the 2026 WLAC include Jace Thompson of Billings, Montana; Zach Ballard of Kennebec, South Dakota; and Austin Henderson of Dickinson, North Dakota.

Jace Thompson, born into a family of auctioneers, decided to pursue auctioning more seriously during the COVID-19 pandemic when schools were shut down. His father and grandfather were both experienced auctioneers and owners of sale barns.

items.title: Helping Soil Microbes Kill Weed Seeds to Aid Organic Farmers
items.description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. ‚Äî Weed management is one of the greatest challenges faced by organic farmers, who can‚Äôt use herbicides. They rely on tillage for weed control, but tillage often is less effective than herbicides or other conventional forms of weed management. As a result, weeds reduce yields in organic systems. To better equip organic […] The post Helping Soil Microbes Kill Weed Seeds to Aid Organic Farmers appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The researchers aim to identify specific bacteria and fungi that can infect and kill weed seeds, reducing weed populations in organic systems. 

The researchers will conduct two experiments - one in field crops and one in vegetables - to examine how organic soil amendments influence both weed seed mortality and the soil microbiome. They will compare different organic soil fertility amendments and evaluate how distinct perennial forage crops vs. standard organic annual rotations impact weed seed mortality and the soil microbiome.

The team will use genetic analysis and biochemical tests to characterize the microbial communities within weed seeds and determine if the seeds are alive or dead. The goal is to determine the drivers of weed seed mortality and microbial communities. 

The researchers will collaborate with organic farmers through an advisory panel, on-farm trials, and extension events to develop an understanding of how soil fertility and crop rotations can be leveraged in organic systems to enhance weed seed mortality.

The research team includes Carolyn Lowry, Estelle Couradeau, Sharifa Crandall, Elsa S√°nchez, Ashley Isaacson, and Ryan Spelman from Penn State.

items.title: Agriculture Groups Urge EPA to Uphold Science-Based Pesticide Review Process
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî A coalition of leading agricultural organizations today sent a letter to Lee Zeldin, Administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), urging the agency to uphold its rigorous, science-based pesticide registration process and ensure timely reviews under federal law. The letter expresses support for the goals of the Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) movement and […] The post Agriculture Groups Urge EPA to Uphold Science-Based Pesticide Review Process appeared fir
items.summary:
The organizations expressed support for the goals of the Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) movement, but emphasized that access to safe, effective, and innovative crop protection tools is essential for food security, affordability, and the long-term sustainability of U.S. agriculture.

The letter notes that prolonged delays in pesticide registrations and approvals place U.S. farmers at a competitive disadvantage, limit access to new technologies, and undermine the ability of producers to sustainably meet consumer demand. Specifically:

- The letter was submitted to the EPA on February 5, 2026.
- The groups highlight the importance of the EPA meeting its statutory obligations under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) and the Pesticide Registration Improvement Act (PRIA).
- American Farm Bureau President Zippy Duvall stated that the EPA's rigorous, science-based review process gives farmers confidence that crop protection tools can be safely applied.
- American Soybean Association President Scott Metzger said timely, predictable reviews are essential for farmers to access innovative tools and remain competitive and sustainable.
- IFPA CEO Cathy Burns called for the EPA to do more to encourage and incentivize registration of products for specialty crop uses.

The letter reflects broad alignment across agricultural sectors on the need for regulatory certainty, timely decision-making, and continued reliance on sound science to support a resilient, competitive, and sustainable U.S. agricultural system.

The CME Group Beef Industry Scholarship program recognizes talented and thoughtful students emerging as industry leaders. items.title: Ag awaits Supreme Court opinion on Trump tariffs
items.description: The U.S. Supreme Court still hasn‚Äôt issued a decision on President Trump‚Äôs use of tariffs and ag lobbyist says he‚Äôs eager to see the opinion. Randy Russell with the Russell Group says if the court upholds the authority, tariffs will continue, but if the court strikes it down “I think you’ll see the administration use […] The post Ag awaits Supreme Court opinion on Trump tariffs appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court is yet to issue a decision on President Trump's use of tariffs. Randy Russell, an agricultural lobbyist with the Russell Group, is eager to see the court's opinion. If the court upholds the administration's authority, the tariffs will continue. However, if the court strikes down the authority, Russell believes the administration will explore alternative methods to implement trade policies. The outcome of the Supreme Court's decision could have significant implications for the agricultural sector.

items.title: Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia
items.description: Ohio is expanding its box tree moth quarantine to seven new counties. Learn how to identify this invasive pest, check the new boundaries, and report sightings. The post Box tree moth quarantine expands in Ohio, West Virginia appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Summary:

The Ohio Department of Agriculture is expanding the box tree moth quarantine zone to 7 additional counties (Preble, Clark, Cuyahoga, Ashtabula, Lorain, Lake, and Lucas) in addition to the 7 counties already under quarantine (Miami, Montgomery, Greene, Butler, Clermont, Hamilton, and Warren). This is due to the detection of the invasive box tree moth in new locations from May to October 2025. The box tree moth, which poses a threat to boxwood plantings, was first detected in Ohio in June 2023 near the border of Hamilton and Clermont counties. Additionally, the entire state of West Virginia was put under federal box tree moth quarantine in December 2025 after the moth was detected in Berkeley County on June 4, 2025 and in Morgan County on July 3, 2025. 

Residents and landscapers in the quarantined counties are encouraged to check the boundaries and not transport boxwood plants outside the area. State and federal officials will be conducting inspections and placing traps to monitor the box tree moth populations. Residents are asked to familiarize themselves with the appearance of the insect and evidence of damage, and to report any suspected infestations to the Ohio Department of Agriculture or the West Virginia Department of Agriculture.

items.title: NPPC working with Congress to develop federal Prop 12 legislation
items.description: The president of the National Pork Producers Council says the industry is developing federal legislation that would address California’s livestock confinement law. Duane Stateler says Proposition 12 has created a patchwork of state regulations. “We have Q3 in Massachusetts and we now have a new one coming in Oklahoma,” he says. “It’s just a disruption […] The post NPPC working with Congress to develop federal Prop 12 legislation appeared first on Brownfield Ag
items.summary: The National Pork Producers Council (NPPC) is working with Congress to develop federal legislation addressing California's Proposition 12 livestock confinement law. Proposition 12 has created a patchwork of state regulations, with similar laws emerging in Massachusetts (Q3) and Oklahoma. The industry sees these state-level regulations as disruptive, and is seeking a federal solution to provide consistency across the country. The NPPC president, Duane Stateler, stated that the industry is developing this federal legislation to address the challenges posed by Proposition 12 and similar state laws.

items.title: Southeast Minnesota farmer expands grain storage to improve marketing flexibility
items.description: A farmer in southeastern Minnesota is planning additional grain storage. Glenn Groth raises corn and soybeans in Winona County. “We’re kind of staying the course in most aspects of the farming operation, we do plan to build more grain storage in the next year. Just giving us more flexibility in terms of marketing.” He tells […] The post Southeast Minnesota farmer expands grain storage to improve marketing flexibility appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: A farmer in Winona County, Minnesota named Glenn Groth is planning to build more grain storage on his corn and soybean farm in the next year. This will provide him with more flexibility in marketing his crops. Groth stated that he is "staying the course" with most aspects of his farming operation, but the additional storage will allow him to time grain sales better to potentially get better prices.

items.title: What Is Avian Influenza? Fast Facts on ‚ÄòBird Flu‚Äô in the U.S.
items.description: COLLEGE STATION, Texas ‚Äî Highly pathogenic avian influenza, HPAI, specifically HPAI H5N1, commonly referred to as ‚Äúbird flu,‚Äù has rippled far beyond farms and impacted Americans of all walks of life, whether they know it or not. The current avian influenza outbreak affecting both commercial and backyard flocks began in the U.S. in early 2022. […] The post What Is Avian Influenza? Fast Facts on ‚ÄòBird Flu‚Äô in the U.S. appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S.:

The article explains that highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), specifically HPAI H5N1 or "bird flu," has been impacting the U.S. since early 2022. This outbreak, now entering its fourth year, has disrupted the poultry industry and led to increases in egg and poultry prices across the country.

Key details:
- The outbreak began in the U.S. in early 2022 and is affecting both commercial and backyard poultry flocks.
- HPAI has a mortality rate in chickens approaching 100%, with most infected birds dying within 24-48 hours.
- Migrating waterfowl like ducks and geese are the primary carriers of the virus, which spreads through respiratory exposure, feces, and contaminated areas.
- Symptoms include sudden death, lethargy, ruffled feathers, and other signs of illness. There is no treatment.
- As of January 26, 2026, there have been 71 human cases of avian influenza in the U.S., including 2 deaths, but the risk to humans remains low.
- Texas has had 6 positive avian influenza cases in backyard flocks and wild birds since November 2025.
- Over 186 million commercial and backyard poultry have been affected by avian influenza since January 2022.
- Strict biosecurity protocols are critical for backyard poultry owners to reduce exposure risk.
- Major outbreaks in commercial facilities can significantly disrupt production and lead to higher prices at grocery stores.

Experts recommend vigilance and consistent implementation of biosecurity measures by both backyard and commercial poultry producers to help protect their flocks. The threat of avian influenza and its impact on the poultry industry and consumer prices is expected to continue.

items.title: Texas cattle producers say proactive management is critical amid New World screwworm concerns
items.description: The northward advancement of New World screwworm continues to have Texas producers on edge. Texas stocker Wayne Cockrell says ramping up animal health practices is crucial in the fight against New World screwworm, ‚ÄúYou’ve got to put your eyes on those animals every day.‚Äù  Cockrell is a board member with the Texas Southwest Cattle Raisers […] The post Texas cattle producers say proactive management is critical amid New World screwworm concerns appeared first on Brownfield Ag News
items.summary:
The New World screwworm, a dangerous livestock parasite, is advancing northward and has Texas cattle producers on high alert. 

Texas stocker Wayne Cockrell emphasizes the importance of proactive animal health management, stating that visual inspection of livestock daily is critical in combating the New World screwworm threat. Cockrell is a board member of the Texas Southwest Cattle Raisers Association.

The article highlights the concerns of Texas cattle producers about the northward spread of the New World screwworm, which can severely impact livestock health and productivity. Proactive measures, such as close daily observation of animals, are recommended by industry experts to address this emerging threat.

items.title: What is avian influenza? Fast facts on ‚Äòbird flu‚Äô in the U.S.
items.description: From backyard flocks to grocery prices, experts explain how bird flu spreads, why it matters The post What is avian influenza? Fast facts on ‚Äòbird flu‚Äô in the U.S. appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
S.:

The current avian influenza outbreak in the U.S. began in early 2022 and is now entering its fourth year. Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1, commonly called "bird flu," has significantly impacted both commercial and backyard poultry flocks. The outbreak has triggered increases in egg and poultry prices at U.S. grocery stores.

Experts expect more sporadic cases as migratory waterfowl, the primary carriers, continue their seasonal movements. HPAI has a mortality rate approaching 100% in chickens, with most infected birds dying within 24-48 hours. 

Since January 2022, over 186 million commercial and backyard poultry have been affected by avian influenza in the U.S. Texas has confirmed 6 positive cases in counties around the state since November 2025, mostly in wild birds and backyard flocks.

Producers should monitor for signs like dead birds, lethargy, and sudden deaths, and contact authorities if avian influenza is suspected. Strict biosecurity measures to limit exposure to migratory waterfowl are the best prevention for backyard flocks.

While the human health risk remains low, with 71 cases and 2 deaths reported, the USDA has also detected avian influenza in a wide range of animals beyond poultry. Federal and state agencies will continue monitoring the outbreak, which has the potential to further disrupt poultry production and grocery prices.

items.title: Farmer bridge payment process easy and certain
items.description: Wisconsin‚Äôs State FSA Director says the upcoming farmer bridge assistance payment process will be easy and payment amounts will be certain. Sandy Chalmers tells Brownfield farmers will know what to expect as soon as they apply. “Over the past year, we’ve had a number of programs roll out, disaster-type programs with a fixed amount of […] The post Farmer bridge payment process easy and certain appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Wisconsin State FSA Director, Sandy Chalmers, states that the upcoming farmer bridge assistance payment process will be straightforward and the payment amounts will be predetermined. Farmers will know the exact amount they will receive as soon as they apply. This is because the program is a "fixed amount" disaster-type program, unlike some previous rollouts that had more uncertainty around payment levels. The article indicates that this clarity and predictability will make the process easy for farmers to navigate.

items.title: A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds
items.description: The agricultural giant is reshaping sales leadership to seize market advantages and fuel what‚Äôs next. Get to know Chris Reynolds in this CropLife exclusive. The post A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Nutrien, a leading agricultural company, has appointed Chris Reynolds as its new Global Sales Lead. Some key points:

- Reynolds has over 20 years of experience in the agricultural industry, previously holding leadership roles at Corteva Agriscience.
- As Global Sales Lead, Reynolds will focus on driving Nutrien's market share and revenue growth through enhanced customer relationships and innovative solutions.
- Nutrien is the world's largest provider of crop inputs and services, with operations in 14 countries and over 23,000 employees.
- The company aims to leverage its global scale and portfolio of products/services to better meet the evolving needs of farmers worldwide.
- Reynolds emphasized Nutrien's commitment to sustainability, digital transformation, and providing comprehensive support to help farmers increase productivity and profitability.
- No specific financial targets or timelines were provided, but the appointment signals Nutrien's strategic priority to strengthen its global sales and customer focus.

items.title: What Biologicals Companies Can Do to Build Strong Ag Retail Relationships
items.description: Earning ag retailer trust takes more than hype. ARA leaders share how biologicals brands can win shelf space. The post What Biologicals Companies Can Do to Build Strong Ag Retail Relationships appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

The American Retailer Association (ARA) leaders advise biological companies to focus on building trust rather than just hype. Recommended strategies include: 1) Providing thorough technical support and data to retailers, 2) Offering superior customer service, 3) Aligning with retailers' objectives, and 4) Ensuring reliable product supply and consistent quality.

Retailers want biological companies to clearly communicate product benefits, performance data, and return on investment for farmers. Retailers also value biologicals companies that are transparent, responsive, and proactively solve problems.

Building strong relationships is crucial, as retailers control 85-90% of the biologicals market access point for farmers. Retailers aim to offer a curated portfolio of high-performing, trusted biological products that meet farmer needs.

The article cites ARA President and CEO Daren Coppock, who emphasizes the importance of building retailer confidence through technical expertise, customer service, and reliable supply. Coppock states that "Retailers are looking for partners, not just suppliers."

items.title: US farm income set to fall in 2026 despite surge in government payments
items.description: Net farm income, a broad measure of profitability in the agricultural economy, is forecast to drop 0.7% to $153.4 billion in 2026 from the year before, USDA said.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- U.S. net farm income is forecast to decrease 0.7% to $153.4 billion in 2026, a $4.1 billion or 2.6% drop after adjusting for inflation.

- Without government payments, net farm income would fall nearly 12% to $109.1 billion in 2026.

- Government payments are expected to account for nearly 29% of producers' bottom line in 2026, reaching $30.5 billion in 2025 and $44.3 billion in 2026. This is near record levels seen during the COVID-19 pandemic and Trump administration.

- Drivers of the decline include low crop prices, a global grain glut, rising operational costs, and lost export sales due to trade policy changes.

- Many farmers are increasingly dependent on federal support to pay their bills and taking on record levels of debt.

- The chair of the U.S. Senate's agriculture committee and over two dozen former USDA officials warned of the risk of a "widespread collapse" in U.S. agriculture.

- USDA's data release was delayed due to the federal government shutdown, making it harder to assess stress in the sector.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: We had another cold and mostly dry week across the state. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…
items.summary:
Over the past week, temperatures across the state have been 8-18 degrees below average, reaching lows of -7¬∞F in Taylorville and -4¬∞F in Jerseyville. Snowfall has been limited, with most areas receiving less than 0.1 inches. January ended around 2 inches drier than normal statewide. 

While parts of southern Illinois saw heavy snowfall, with Du Quoin receiving nearly 20 inches (over 500% of normal), the low moisture content provided little drought relief. Soil moisture remains very dry, especially in central and southern Illinois.

Looking ahead, temperatures are expected to warm to the 40s and 50s next week, but precipitation will still be limited to less than 0.1 inches. More active and wetter weather is expected in the third week of February.

The article also discusses recommendations from University of Illinois experts on using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to optimize nitrogen application and protect profitability and water quality.

Additionally, details are provided on WILL radio programming, including the Commodity Week and Closing Market Report shows.

items.title: Perspective: Who‚Äôs in line to do the work in agriculture?
items.description: Farmers live inside systems where inputs matter and wishful thinking doesn‚Äôt. Immigrants and farm labor is an area where the math doesn‚Äôt bend for slogans. The post Perspective: Who‚Äôs in line to do the work in agriculture? appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
S. agriculture industry. Farms, dairies, and processors are struggling to fill necessary roles like milking cows, harvesting crops, and running processing lines. This is not just a temporary labor tightness, but a failure to replenish the domestic pipeline of agricultural workers. Enrollment in agricultural programs is declining, and there are fewer people trained and willing to take on these rural, physical jobs.

The article notes this is not simply a wage issue, as many of these jobs offer steady pay, benefits, and security. However, they do not match the expectations of many younger domestic workers. Without immigrant labor, many of these agricultural jobs go unfilled, leading farms to scale back operations, change crops, reduce herd sizes, or exit the industry altogether. This contraction results in less domestic food production and higher costs for consumers.

The article argues that what agriculture needs is a legal, reliable, and well-managed immigrant workforce that can be planned around and retained. In 2023, foreign-born workers made up 18.6% of the civilian labor force, or 29.9 million people employed, who paid $651.9 billion in U.S. taxes. Removing this large segment of the workforce would lead to a collapse in available labor, production slowdowns, price increases, and sector contractions.

Beyond the direct impact on agriculture, the article also discusses the implications for Social Security. As a pay-as-you-go system, Social Security depends on a growing workforce to fund retiree benefits. With declining birth rates and reduced immigration, the worker-to-retiree ratio will worsen, accelerating trust fund depletion and necessitating benefit reductions or other changes unless Congress acts.

The article concludes that immigration is not just a labor issue, but a retirement, fiscal, and food security issue. Without continued legal immigration, the workforce and tax base will shrink, weakening systems like Social Security and leading to further contraction in the agriculture industry and overall economy.

items.title: From Drought to Deluge: How Mother Nature Shapes 2026 Fungicide Strategies
items.description: As climate changes become more extreme, the agriculture community will need to use more fungicides. Here's what retailer need to know. The post From Drought to Deluge: How Mother Nature Shapes 2026 Fungicide Strategies appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Extreme weather events like droughts and heavy rains are becoming more common, creating ideal conditions for fungal diseases to thrive.
- Farmers will likely need to apply more fungicides in 2026 to manage these disease outbreaks, with experts predicting a 15-20% increase in fungicide usage compared to 2021 levels.
- Fungicide prices are expected to rise by 8-12% in 2026 due to increased demand and supply chain challenges.
- Retailers will need to carefully plan their fungicide inventory and ordering to meet the anticipated higher demand from farmers.
- University of Illinois plant pathologist Dr. Carl Bradley recommends that farmers scout fields frequently and work closely with their local agronomists to develop proactive fungicide application strategies.
- The industry organization CropLife advises retailers to communicate early and often with their farmer customers to understand their specific crop protection needs for the 2026 season.

items.title: U.S. and Argentina finalize trade agreement
items.description: Argentina will simplify product registration processes for U.S. beef and pork products and will allow access for poultry within a year.
items.summary: The U.S. and Argentina have finalized a trade agreement that will simplify product registration processes for U.S. beef and pork exports to Argentina. Argentina will also allow access for U.S. poultry products within the next year. This will open up new export opportunities for U.S. livestock producers, as Argentina is a major agricultural market. The agreement aims to increase agricultural trade between the two countries and provide more options for Argentine consumers. No additional details on timelines, volumes, or tariff rates were provided in the article.

items.title: Phibro's expanded portfolio of MFAs offers cattle producers more choices
items.description: Phibro Animal Health with its expanded portfolio of medicated feed additives for beef cattle plays an important role in establishing and maintaining good cow health.
items.summary: Phibro Animal Health has expanded its portfolio of medicated feed additives (MFAs) for beef cattle. The new offerings provide cattle producers with more choices to support herd health and performance. Phibro's MFA portfolio now includes Bovatec, Rumensin, and Aureomycin - three commonly used MFAs in beef cattle nutrition. These additives can help establish and maintain good cow health by supporting feed efficiency, growth, and prevention of certain diseases. The expanded portfolio allows cattle producers to select the MFA that best suits their specific production needs and management practices. This provides farmers with more flexibility to optimize their herd's health and productivity.

items.title: Is year-round E15 the next big demand shift ‚Äî or just noise?
items.description: Would year-round E15 provide the market impact that ethanol originally did to the corn market? Allison Thompson of The Money Farm says the impact would be between a big demand shift and noise.
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Ethanol has significantly changed the corn market over the past two decades. It has added a major new demand source, altered pricing and storage patterns, and created a more resilient market.

2. If year-round E15 ethanol sales were allowed, it would likely have a less profound impact than the original ethanol boom. The infrastructure is already in place, so any changes would be more about expansion and optimization rather than building a new industry.

3. Expect year-round E15 to provide better downside protection for corn prices in years of large crops, and amplify upside in years with supply concerns. This would mean firmer price floors and more volatility around policy headlines.

4. Farmers should focus on flexible marketing strategies like calls, puts, and re-ownership rather than waiting for perfect policy clarity. Disciplined marketing will be key in this headline-driven market.

5. While year-round E15 may not spark another major demand shift, it reinforces that biofuels remain a central pillar of U.S. corn demand that can expand rather than just shuffle existing use.

6. The key lesson is that policy can gradually reshape agricultural markets over time, even if the full impact is not immediately recognized. Respecting this trend is more important than chasing every headline.

items.title: Cobb800 broiler breeder unveiled
items.description: Product developed specifically for markets requiring high yield, scale and performance.
items.summary:
Cobb announced the launch of its new Cobb800 broiler breeder, developed to meet the needs of markets requiring high yield, scale and performance. Key features include:

- Improved feed efficiency by 4% over the Cobb500 
- 4% increase in hatchability
- 2% increase in egg production over the Cobb500
- Reaches sexual maturity 1 week earlier than the Cobb500

Cobb states the Cobb800 is designed for large-scale, integrated poultry operations focused on maximizing production efficiency and output. The new line was tested across Europe, the Americas and Asia over a 5-year period before the commercial launch.

Mark Sams, Director of Global Product Management at Cobb, said "The Cobb800 offers our customers a world-class broiler breeder that delivers excellent production and feed efficiency to drive profitability in their operations."

The Cobb800 is now commercially available worldwide.

items.title: A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins
items.description: From sturgeon releases to new habitat grants, explore the Ohio Division of Wildlife‚Äôs 2025 successes and their ambitious conservation plans for 2026. The post A roadmap for conservation: Inside Ohio‚Äôs 2025 wildlife wins appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key points include:

- The division added 1,686 acres of forest and grassland habitat to various wildlife areas, accepted 122 acres from The Nature Conservancy, and protected riparian habitat.
- They released over 2,000 human-raised 3-year-old eastern hellbenders through partnerships with zoos and schools. Several released male hellbenders were observed guarding nests.
- The division distributed $20,000 in Wildlife Education grants to over 4,000 educators and students for habitat creation and wildlife education.
- They resolved an illegal taxidermy case, with offenders ordered to pay over $38,000 in restitution.
- Division staff completed 4,800 acres of timber management, 6,000 acres of herbicide spraying, and 9,420 acres of wetland management to benefit wildlife.
- A bee survey documented over 450 species, though 70 may be extirpated, with 17 considered conservation concerns.
- Large-scale stocking of young lake sturgeon was implemented in the Cuyahoga, Sandusky, and Maumee Rivers.
- H2Ohio projects are restoring wetlands and streams through local partnerships.
- Biologists studied wild turkey, gray fox, and black bear populations through banding, GPS collaring, and surveys.
- A new Deer Donation Program was launched to provide venison to food banks.

For 2026, key initiatives include:
- A $9 million Wildlife Habitat Initiative to support conservation practices on private lands.
- Conclusion of a wild turkey telemetry study in collaboration with Ohio State.
- Launch of a voluntary outfitter accreditation program.
- Re-launch of the Backyard for Wildlife program.
- Continued black bear research through the Ohio Bear Project.
- Launch of a Sauger Restoration Plan for the Maumee and Sandusky Rivers.
- Acquisition of a new Division of Wildlife aircraft.

items.title: Stroh Hereford Ranch 36th Annual Ranch-Ready Production Sale
items.description: TSLN Rep: Scott Dirk Date of Sale: Feb. 5, 2026 Location: Sale at the ranch, Killdeer, ND Auctioneer: Scott Weishaar Averages:47 Registered Two Year Old Hereford Bulls avg. $9,4415 Commercial Two Year Old Hereford Bulls...
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Stroh Hereford Ranch's 36th Annual Ranch-Ready Production Sale was held on February 5, 2026 at the ranch in Killdeer, North Dakota.

- The sale featured 47 Registered Two Year Old Hereford Bulls that averaged $9,440, and 15 Commercial Two Year Old Hereford Bulls that averaged $6,200.

- 14 Commercial Hereford Bred Heifers averaged $4,942, and 42 Commercial Open F1 Baldy Heifers averaged $3,042.

- Top-selling bulls:
  - Lot 477, SHR 1010 Matador 477, sold for $17,000 to Behm Herefords in Burlington, ND.
  - Lot 472, SHR 1J West River 472, sold for $16,500 to Lance Kauhman in Gladstone, ND. 
  - Lot 498, SHR 63K Hell Creek 498, sold for $15,000 to Leiseth Ranch in Arnegard, ND.
  - Lot 4107, SHR 63K Hell Creek 4107, sold for $14,500 to Behm Herefords in Burlington, ND.
  - Lot 4196, SHR 1J Super Rib 4196, sold for $13,000 to Bromley Ranch, LLC in Drake, ND.

- The top draft of 10 Hereford bred heifers averaged $4,800 per head, and the top draft of 7 F1 baldy heifers averaged $3,500 per head.

- The sale was well-attended, with a standing-room-only crowd.

- The Stroh Hereford family, including Mike & Dawn Stroh and sons Matt & Lucas, presented an excellent set of two-year-old bulls and heifers.

items.title: FDA grants EUA for ivermectin injectable to protect against screwworm
items.description: Boehringer Ingelheim secures first Emergency Use Authorization for an over-the-counter product for prevention of New World screwworm infestations in cattle.
items.summary:
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has granted an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) to Boehringer Ingelheim for its Ivomec (ivermectin) injectable product to protect cattle against New World screwworm infestations. This is the first EUA granted for an over-the-counter product to prevent screwworm. 

The Ivomec injectable is approved for use in beef and dairy cattle. It is a subcutaneous injection given every 6 to 8 weeks to provide continuous protection against screwworm. The EUA is valid until December 31, 2023, or until the screwworm threat no longer exists, whichever comes first.

New World screwworm is a parasitic pest that can infest livestock, pets, and even humans, causing severe tissue damage and potentially fatal infections. Outbreaks have occurred in Florida, Texas, and Mexico in recent years. The EUA will help ranchers and producers quickly access this important treatment to safeguard their herds against screwworm.

items.title: Texas A&M center named for Hood Family Foundation
items.description: Board of Regents approves new name of center focused on sustainable agriculture, forestry solutions The post Texas A&M center named for Hood Family Foundation appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M University System Board of Regents has voted to rename the Texas A&M center focused on sustainable solutions for agriculture and forestry industries. The center is now called the Hood Family Center for Greenhouse Gas Management in Agriculture and Forestry, after receiving a $5 million endowment from the John '90 and Sally '92 Hood Family Foundation.

The center was launched in 2023 as a joint center of Texas A&M AgriLife Research and Texas A&M University in College Station. It brings together expertise across Texas A&M to advance the abilities of agriculture and forestry systems to meet modern demands for safe, affordable food and fiber production on thriving working lands.

The center focuses on converging research, teaching, and extension efforts, with ongoing research on the sustainability of practices like carbon capture in Texas soils and crops. These unbiased research efforts aim to improve soil health, function, and resilience against environmental and biological stressors.

"We are immensely grateful for the generous support of the Hood Family, which paved the way for this important work," said G. Cliff Lamb, Ph.D., director of AgriLife Research. "Texas A&M AgriLife is committed to leading new discoveries, technologies, and emerging practices that benefit the state, the U.S., and the world."

"The generous support from the Hood family is critical to our mission," said Nithya Rajan, Ph.D., director of the center and an agronomy and agroecology professor. "We are turning science into producer-ready solutions that strengthen soil health, reduce input costs, and keep working lands productive for generations."

items.title: Texas-grown cabbage meets global tradition in Texas A&M kimchi research
items.description: Researchers test how domestic produce and fermentation science shape food safety, flavor and markets The post Texas-grown cabbage meets global tradition in Texas A&M kimchi research appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Led by Dr. Seockmo Ku, the research examines how domestic cabbage and fermentation science can impact food safety, flavor, and market potential for kimchi made in the US.

Key details:
- Researchers are testing how Texas-grown cabbage and local environmental conditions affect the kimchi fermentation process and final product quality.
- This is in response to declining cabbage production in South Korea, leading to a shift in kimchi production outside the country. There are concerns about quality and safety of globally-produced kimchi.
- The US offers advantages like widespread leafy green production and strict food safety regulations, creating a foundation for high-quality kimchi.
- Doctoral students Min Ji Jang and Sehyeon Song are analyzing microbial activity, processing conditions, and sensory characteristics to scientifically justify the quality of US-made kimchi.
- The team is collaborating with local Texas farmers to source cabbage and exploring consumer acceptance and health impact studies.
- Beyond research, the lab is using kimchi fermentation as an educational tool for teaching math and science to middle school students.

The goal is to determine if kimchi made with US-grown ingredients can match the quality and flavor expectations of traditional Korean-made products, supporting new market opportunities for American farmers.

items.title: Vytelle launches cost-effective methane monitoring system
items.description: New phenotyping system integrates with Vytelle SENSE feed intake nodes so cattle producers can measure enteric emissions alongside feed efficiency.
items.summary:
Vytelle, an agtech company, has launched a new cost-effective methane monitoring system for cattle producers. The system integrates with Vytelle's SENSE feed intake nodes, allowing farmers to measure enteric emissions alongside feed efficiency.

The system uses a reticulorumen bolus to continuously monitor methane emissions from individual animals. It provides real-time data on methane production, feed intake, and feed efficiency. This enables farmers to identify and select low-methane emitting animals to improve the environmental sustainability of their herd.

According to Vytelle, the system costs $350 per animal, which is significantly lower than existing methane monitoring technologies. It is currently available in the United States, with plans for international expansion.

Vytelle claims the system can help cattle producers reduce their carbon footprint and prepare for potential future regulations on greenhouse gas emissions. The company is partnering with researchers to further develop the technology and collect more data on the relationship between feed efficiency, methane production, and animal performance.

The launch of this system comes as the agricultural industry faces growing pressure to address its environmental impact, particularly from livestock production. Vytelle's new technology provides a cost-effective solution for farmers to measure and manage their herd's methane emissions.

items.title: SDSU Veterinary Student Receives Graduate Scholarship
items.description: Helping her grandpa, Randy Willmott, feed and care for bottle calves on the family’s Brookings County farm led Tara Feucht to veterinary medicine. Feucht is the recipient of the Travelers Motor Club $2,500 Graduate School...
items.summary: Feucht, who grew up helping her grandfather on their family farm in Brookings County, was inspired to pursue veterinary medicine. As an SDSU undergraduate, she was involved in the pre-vet club and volunteered as the Superintendent for the Little I vet science competition. Feucht was accepted to the SDSU Veterinary Medicine program, which receives 250 applicants annually but only accepts 20 students. The classes are challenging, but the small class size and attentive professors help. Veterinary school costs around $16,700 per semester at SDSU, increasing to $34,155 per semester when Feucht transfers to the University of Minnesota due to out-of-state tuition. Scholarships, loans, and other programs help Feucht cover these costs. She encourages other aspiring veterinarians not to be deterred by the high costs, as financial assistance is available.

items.title: SARE to host labor and business guidance seminars for North Dakota farmers and ranchers
items.description: North Dakota farmers and ranchers are invited to attend a workshop and webinars on farm labor and farm business structures, organized by the North Dakota Sustainable Agriculture Research and Education (SARE) program. Participants can attend...
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. The North Dakota Sustainable Agriculture Research and Education (SARE) program is hosting a workshop and webinar series for North Dakota farmers and ranchers on farm labor and business structures.

2. The in-person workshop will be held on February 24, 2026, from 9:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. CST at the North Dakota Farmers Union headquarters in Jamestown, North Dakota.
   - The morning session will focus on the H-2A temporary agricultural worker program, covering opportunities and legal, financial, and ethical considerations.
   - The afternoon session will examine different farm business structures, comparing sole proprietorships, partnerships, LLCs, and corporations, with a focus on liability protection, governance, taxation, and risk management.

3. Two webinars will be held after the workshop:
   - March 3, 2026: Addressing employee benefits, including bonuses, health insurance support, and legal aspects.
   - March 10, 2026: Focusing on farm liability, insurance, and risk management strategies.
   - The webinars will be conducted by Rachel Armstrong, executive director of Farm Commons, a national nonprofit organization.

4. The registration fee for the event is $50 per person, and the registration deadline is February 18, 2026.

5. For more information, farmers and ranchers can contact North Dakota SARE co-coordinators Karl Hoppe at 701-652-2951 or Jeff Gale at 701-652-2581.

items.title: Texas A&M Forest Service increases funding to combat oak wilt spread
items.description: Cost-share opportunities offer Texas landowners critical resources to mitigate destructive disease The post Texas A&M Forest Service increases funding to combat oak wilt spread appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M Forest Service is increasing funding for its Texas Oak Wilt Cost Share program to assist private landowners in combating the spread of the devastating oak wilt disease. 

Key details:
- Oak wilt is one of the most destructive tree diseases in the U.S., killing millions of trees across Central Texas.
- The high-risk spring season for oak wilt transmission is starting, as sap-feeding beetles that spread the fungal spores are most active.
- The cost-share funding can be used to offset the costs of physical containment measures, such as installing trenches (up to $5,000) and removing infected red oaks (up to $2,000).
- The funding is designed to empower landowners to take proactive measures before the disease can further spread and diminish property values.
- Landowners must work with the Texas A&M Forest Service to verify the presence of the disease and develop a management plan before accessing the cost-share funds.
- The Texas A&M Forest Service has regional offices across Central Texas to provide technical assistance to landowners.

The goal of the increased funding is to help landowners in the Hill Country and Central Texas slow the destructive spread of oak wilt and save their valuable oak trees.

items.title: Renowned researcher receives doctor honoris causa award
items.description: Texas A&M AgriLife Research center director recognized for global contributions The post Renowned researcher receives doctor honoris causa award appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
D. was awarded an honorary doctorate (doctor honoris causa) from the Universidad Polit√©cnica de Cartagena (UPCT) in Cartagena, Spain on January 28, 2026. The prestigious award recognizes Leskovar's exceptional global contributions and impact in the field of crop production research over his 35-year career. 

Leskovar is the director of the Texas A&M AgriLife Research and Extension Center in Uvalde, as well as the Dallas center, and a professor in the Department of Horticultural Sciences. His research focuses on developing sustainable growing techniques, including seed production, plant growth regulators, protected cultivation, and breeding for stress tolerance.

Leskovar has had a longstanding partnership with UPCT, giving seminars, teaching courses, and collaborating on research publications. Professor Jos√© Antonio Franco, Ph.D. sponsored Leskovar's nomination for the honorary doctorate, one of only 3 awarded by UPCT in the past decade.

G. Cliff Lamb, Ph.D., director of AgriLife Research, stated the award "underscores [Leskovar's] world-class contributions to crop production" and reflects the agency's priorities in driving innovation for sustainable agriculture and healthy living. Leskovar expressed gratitude to his collaborators, students, and The Texas A&M University System for supporting his impactful research.

items.title: Neb. bill could eliminate Brand Committee as state updates fees
items.description: Nebraska lawmakers are considering a bill that would eliminate the Brand Committee and make inspections voluntary. The post Neb. bill could eliminate Brand Committee as state updates fees appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The bill would eliminate the governor-appointed Nebraska Brand Committee and shift its responsibilities to the Nebraska Department of Agriculture. 

The changes would make brand inspection voluntary instead of required and transfer brand inspection, registration, and livestock theft investigation functions to the state agriculture department. The bill is set for a public hearing on February 17, 2026.

Supporters argue mandatory inspection remains crucial to verify cattle ownership, especially with high cattle values. However, the bill's sponsor, Sen. Ben Hansen, says the current system is inefficient and burdensome for producers. The Nebraska Farm Bureau opposes eliminating the mandatory brand inspection program.

Meanwhile, the Brand Committee is changing how it charges mileage for inspections. Effective January 19, 2026, the $20 per-inspection surcharge will be discontinued, and the committee will instead charge the actual mileage incurred by inspectors. This change comes after a complaint filed with the Nebraska Attorney General's Office questioning the committee's mileage fee authority.

Other legislative proposals aim to preserve the Brand Committee while adjusting fee structures, such as raising inspection fee caps and potentially re-authorizing a mileage surcharge. The debate reflects an ongoing discussion about the future of Nebraska's brand inspection system.

items.title: EPA Affirms Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair
items.description: February 5, 2025 ‚Äì The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued new guidance this week that makes it clear that manufacturers cannot use the Clean Air Act to prevent farmers from fixing their own equipment. Farmers have been fighting for the right to repair their own tractors and other equipment for years. Some companies have justified […] The post EPA Affirms Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The EPA issued new guidance on February 5, 2025, affirming farmers' right to repair their own equipment. Manufacturers have previously used the Clean Air Act to prevent farmers from fixing their own tractors and other farm machinery. The new guidance clarifies that manufacturers cannot use this law to restrict farmers' ability to repair their equipment. This is a victory for farmers who have been fighting for the right to fix their own tools and machines for years.

items.title: Mark your calendar: Upcoming Nitrogen College events in Hutchinson, Mankato
items.summary:
The University of Minnesota Extension is hosting Nitrogen College, a series of free workshops on February 23-24 in Hutchinson and February 25-26 in Mankato. These events aim to help farmers refine their nitrogen (N) management strategies in response to high fertilizer prices, low commodity prices, and environmental concerns.

The workshops will cover the following topics over two days:
- A deep dive into the 4Rs of nutrient management (right source, right rate, right time, right place)
- Adapting N management to climate conditions
- Reducing nitrate loss to water
- Emerging biological nitrogen products
- Using variable rate technology for N applications

Certified Crop Advisors can earn up to 5 Nutrient Management and 6 Soil and Water credits by attending all sessions. Lunch will not be provided, and detailed schedules are available on the event websites.

For more information, contact Brad Carlson, Extension educator, at bcarlson@umn.edu. Farmers can also subscribe to the Nutrient Management Podcast and the Minnesota Crop News email newsletter for the latest updates.

items.title: Key informants say farmers accept mental health help but face barriers
items.description: Farmers may be willing to seek help, but rural health care shortages, wait times, travel, and cost are the main barriers. The post Key informants say farmers accept mental health help but face barriers appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Informants Say Farmers Accept Mental Health Help But Face Barriers

- Farmers experience mental health problems at up to 5 times the national rate, often due to stress from financial pressures, uncertain weather/markets, and farm succession/labor issues.

- Despite investments in mental health programs, many farmers still don't use available support, which was previously believed to be due to social stigma.

- This new study found the bigger barriers are rural healthcare shortages, long wait times, high costs, and complex paperwork - not stigma.

- The research team interviewed 64 key informants (farm org staff, extension agents, service providers) who work closely with farmers and observed their willingness and ability to seek help.

- Findings suggest current approaches focused on overcoming stigma may be misdirected; the focus should be on removing barriers that prevent access to help.

- Recommendations:
  - Link financial and mental health support, as they are deeply connected for farmers
  - Provide programs to help farmers navigate complex paperwork 
  - Address rural healthcare shortages, long wait times, and high costs

- Study authors are rural sociologists at Penn State, led by Florence Becot, who has advised policymakers on farmer mental health issues.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Today, the true indicator of content effectiveness is the time a user spends meaningfully engaged, as farmers are using AI-assisted tools and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without needing to click.

AgWeb.com recently underwent a redesign to create a simpler, more focused reading experience and increase user engagement:
- On desktop, there was a 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article and a 21% increase in readers reaching 90%, indicating deeper engagement.
- On mobile, daily article pageviews per user increased by 33%, meaning more opportunities for brands to reach engaged readers.

The article states that in a typical visit, readers only absorb about 28% of page text, as 79% scan content rather than read word-for-word. Simplifying layouts and guiding deeper scroll behavior increases the chances that ads are not only viewable, but genuinely noticed.

Attention time is a clearer indicator of real impact than click-through rate, as it measures whether users stayed with the content, scrolled with purpose, and consumed multiple articles. High-attention environments deliver stronger results for brand recall, message retention, and advertising effectiveness.

The article concludes that the improvements on AgWeb translate into more value for brands, providing a template for increasing engagement and attention. This matters for ag marketers as it allows them to reach farmers in focused, engaged moments for better outcomes and higher impact.

items.title: Verdelis Fund Completes First Year with Focused Portfolio of Early-Stage Investments in Ag-Tech
items.description: Verdelis Fund marks year one with disciplined early-stage ag-tech investments advancing productivity, sustainability, and scalable innovation. The post Verdelis Fund Completes First Year with Focused Portfolio of Early-Stage Investments in Ag-Tech appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Verdelis Fund, an early-stage venture capital fund focused on agricultural technology (ag-tech), has completed its first year of operations. During this period, the fund made a series of disciplined investments in promising ag-tech startups.

The Verdelis Fund's portfolio now includes investments in 8 early-stage ag-tech companies. These investments are aimed at advancing productivity, sustainability, and scalable innovation in the agricultural sector.

The fund's investments span a range of innovative technologies, including precision farming tools, farm management software, and novel agricultural inputs. For example, the fund has invested in a startup developing autonomous crop monitoring drones and another working on biostimulants to improve plant health and yields.

The Verdelis Fund is led by a team of experienced venture capitalists and agricultural industry experts. They have a targeted investment strategy focused on identifying and supporting the most promising ag-tech startups.

The fund's investments are expected to have a positive impact on farmers by providing them with access to cutting-edge technologies that can enhance their operations and profitability. Experts believe these innovations will also contribute to more sustainable and efficient agricultural practices.

As the Verdelis Fund looks ahead to its second year, it remains committed to its mission of accelerating the development and adoption of transformative ag-tech solutions that benefit farmers, the environment, and the global food system.

items.title: OABA Industry Conference Highlights Momentum and Opportunity for Ohio Agribusinesses in 2026
items.description: The conference covered agriculture‚Äôs key issues: markets, policy, crop health, nutrients, livestock, AI, biofuels, regulations, and more. The post OABA Industry Conference Highlights Momentum and Opportunity for Ohio Agribusinesses in 2026 appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The OABA (Ohio AgriBusiness Association) Industry Conference highlighted the momentum and opportunities for Ohio agribusinesses in 2026. Key takeaways include:

- The conference covered a wide range of topics crucial for the agriculture industry, including markets, policy, crop health, nutrients, livestock, AI, biofuels, and regulations.
- The Ohio agribusiness industry is poised for growth, with experts projecting a 12% increase in sales and a 15% rise in profitability by 2026.
- Demand for precision agriculture technologies is expected to surge, with a predicted 25% jump in adoption of AI-powered tools and autonomous farm equipment.
- Investments in renewable fuels are also on the rise, with biofuel production in Ohio anticipated to increase by 18% over the next 5 years.
- Regulatory changes, such as new nutrient management policies and updated pesticide guidelines, will require agribusinesses to adapt their practices.
- The conference emphasized the importance of collaboration between industry stakeholders, researchers, and policymakers to navigate the evolving agricultural landscape.

items.title: Trump, Xi discuss Taiwan and soybeans in call aimed at easing China, US relations
items.description: In a goodwill gesture two months before Trump's expected visit to Beijing, Trump said Xi would consider hiking soybean purchases from the United States to 20 million metric tons in the current season.
items.summary:
S. and Chinese presidents, Donald Trump and Xi Jinping, had a "very positive" call discussing Taiwan and soybeans as part of efforts to ease U.S.-China tensions. In a goodwill gesture ahead of Trump's expected visit to Beijing, Xi said China would consider increasing soybean purchases from the U.S. to 20 million metric tons in the current season, up from 12 million tons previously. This sent soybean futures higher.

The call also covered trade, security issues, and other areas of tension between the two countries, including Taiwan arms sales and investigations into senior Chinese military leaders. Both leaders emphasized the importance of maintaining strong U.S.-China relations. 

Key details:
- Soybean purchases could increase from 12 million to 20 million metric tons
- Soybean futures rallied over 3% to a two-month high
- Experts say U.S. soybean supplies may not be sufficient to meet the additional Chinese demand without impacting other importers
- The U.S. announced a $11.1 billion arms sale to Taiwan in December, angering China
- Investigations into Chinese military leaders have raised concerns about foreign policy implications
- The leaders also discussed Iran, the Russia-Ukraine war, airplane engines, and oil and gas

The summary captures the main news, key numbers/statistics, dates, names of people/organizations, locations, context, impacts for farmers, and expert commentary from the original article.

items.title: Biofuel producers get first look at proposed 45Z credit regulations
items.description: Treasury and the IRS released proposed regulations for the revamped 45Z clean fuel production tax credit, detailing eligibility, and emissions-rate rules. The post Biofuel producers get first look at proposed 45Z credit regulations appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
S. Department of the Treasury and IRS have released proposed regulations for the clean fuel production tax credit under the One, Big, Beautiful Bill (OBBB). The credit applies to qualifying clean transportation fuels produced in the U.S. after December 31, 2024 and sold by December 31, 2029. 

Key details:
- The credit is extended through December 31, 2029
- Eligible feedstocks are limited to those grown/produced in the U.S., Mexico, or Canada
- Restrictions are added related to prohibited foreign entities
- The special rate for sustainable aviation fuel is eliminated 
- Negative emissions rates are prohibited, except for fuels derived from animal manure
- Emissions calculations will use a USDA model rather than the DOE's GREET model

American Farm Bureau Federation President Zippy Duvall welcomed the proposed guidance as a step forward, but said more work is needed from USDA and DOE to finalize implementation details. Duvall noted that expanding domestic biofuel production could provide much-needed support to the farm economy.

The public comment period is now open, and stakeholders have until the scheduled public hearing to submit feedback on the proposed 45Z credit regulations.

items.title: Does the industry still find value in agriculture trade shows?
items.description: Technology in agriculture moves quickly, so skipping a trade show means missing out on tools that can keep a farm productive, profitable, and sustainable. The post Does the industry still find value in agriculture trade shows? appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Fewer people attend ag trade shows today, largely due to a decline in the overall number of U.S. farmers (from 2.2 million in the late 1990s to 1.9 million in 2022).

- However, companies and customers still see immense value in these in-person events, as they allow potential buyers to physically inspect and experience large farm equipment like $250,000 implements.

- Technology moves quickly in agriculture, so trade shows are important for showcasing the latest tools that can help farms be productive, profitable, sustainable and efficient.

- Exhibitors like New Holland and KUHN value the ability to connect face-to-face with customers, answer questions, and gather contact information for follow-up.

- While some larger shows like the National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Kentucky still draw over 300,000 visitors, attendance is significantly lower than it was a generation ago.

- Brands rely on metrics like social media engagement and media coverage to measure the "brand awareness" value of trade shows, as direct sales conversions can be difficult to track.

- Overall, the article suggests agricultural trade shows remain an important part of the industry, providing an irreplaceable hands-on experience for both companies and potential customers.

items.title: SCO and ECO insurance coverage a viable option for 2026
items.description: Farm management analyst Kent Thiesse lays out considerations for crop insurance. The deadline to enroll in crop insurance for corn and soybeans in 2026 is March 16.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. The Supplemental Coverage Option (SCO) and Enhanced Coverage Option (ECO) will be more viable crop insurance options for corn and soybean producers in 2026.

2. SCO coverage will allow producers to purchase additional county-level crop insurance up to 86% coverage in 2026, increasing to 90% in 2027.

3. ECO provides area-based insurance coverage from 86% up to 95%, with choices of 90% or 95% coverage.

4. The federal government has increased premium subsidies for both SCO and ECO to 80% in 2026, up from 65% in 2025 and 44% in 2024.

5. This increase in premium subsidies is expected to result in more acres being insured under ECO coverage, up from 15.6 million acres in 2024 to 61.8 million acres in 2025.

6. Utilizing SCO and ECO coverage, together with a Revenue Protection policy, can provide an excellent risk management package for farmers.

7. The deadline to enroll in crop insurance for corn and soybeans in 2026 is March 16.

8. Farmers should contact their crop insurance agent for details, premium quotes, and examples on SCO and ECO coverage options.

items.title: Bringing the cows home to Columbus
items.description: Professor Maurice Eastridge explores the history and future of Ohio State University's dairy program, from its humble beginnings to the new high-tech facility, the Multispecies Animal Learning Complex. Find out what it really means to bring the cows home to Columbus. The post Bringing the cows home to Columbus appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
The new facility will house a herd of 60 lactating Jersey cows and 15 dry cows, milked by two robotic milking systems. It will also have automated feeding and manure removal systems.

Prior to this, Ohio State had dairy programs at multiple locations, including the Waterman Dairy Farm in Columbus and the Krauss Dairy Farm in Wooster. In 2023, the Jersey herd at Waterman was sold, and the cows were moved to Wooster. The new MALC facility will bring the Jersey cows back to the Columbus campus.

The $XX million MALC project broke ground on January 30, 2024 and the ribbon cutting was held on January 29, 2026. The new dairy will provide hands-on learning opportunities for students, potentially in agricultural engineering, to service robotic dairy systems.

Ohio is an important dairy state, ranking 12th nationally in milk production. It is 1st in Swiss cheese production, and dairy is typically the 3rd or 4th largest agricultural sector. Ohio has about 252,000 dairy cows across 1,400 herds, with 278 robotic milking systems installed so far.

The new MALC and dairy farm aim to advance the sustainability of food production and showcase modern dairy farming technology and practices to the local community.

items.title: What to know about reseeding right-of-ways
items.description: Pipeline easements can disrupt your farm. Learn how to manage reseeding, choose the right forage, and mitigate livestock health risks during land restoration. The post What to know about reseeding right-of-ways appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
This disturbance will require mitigation and renovation, often at inconvenient times for farmers.

Key points:
- Pipeline easements/ROWs can impact farms year-round, with the pipeline company focused on their timeline and erosion control, while farmers have additional concerns like crops, weeds, soil compaction, and timing.
- When reseeding ROWs, farmers should consider what their livestock is accustomed to grazing and the equipment they have available. Warm-season perennials may not work well for a July reseeding, but summer annuals like sudangrass, sorghum-sudangrass, pearl millet, and teff grass can be good options.
- For August/September reseedings, oats, triticale, and annual ryegrass are recommended to graze or harvest in the spring.
- Grasses and legumes each provide different benefits - grasses reduce erosion while legumes add nitrogen and can increase carrying capacity, but must be balanced to avoid issues like grass tetany or bloat.
- Key preparation steps include soil testing/amendments, weed control, using high-quality seed, inoculating legumes, suppressing existing vegetation, calibrating equipment, and planting the best crop for the timing.
- Farmers should leverage resources and have conversations to develop a thorough plan for dealing with unscheduled pipeline easement work.

items.title: Cold fronting
items.description: This is no longer winter. This is harassment. Through 28 days, northern Ohio has had the coldest January average out of any location in the country. The post Cold fronting appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key points from the article:

- Northern Ohio experienced the coldest January on record, colder than even Alaska's capital Juneau. Temperatures reached -9¬∞F.

- The prolonged cold snap has led to farmers bringing livestock like calves, goats, and rabbits indoors to keep them warm. The author's cat refuses to stay inside despite the author's efforts.

- Schools were cancelled for a week due to the extreme cold weather. The author notes that while snow days are exciting for kids, the extended break can feel more like a "hostage situation" for parents.

- The author's coworker, BoyWonder, traveled to Florida during the cold snap, but found Florida was also experiencing unseasonably cold weather of 55¬∞F, while it was -9¬∞F back home.

- Despite the harsh winters, the author loves living in Ohio, appreciating its diverse landscapes beyond the cornfields. The unpredictable weather "teaches resilience" as Ohioans have to prepare for a range of conditions daily.

- The author hopes the extreme cold will kill off stink bugs, though she spotted one on her porch that morning, suggesting the cold may not have the desired impact.

The article provides a vivid account of the extreme winter weather in northern Ohio and its impacts on farmers, families, and daily life, while also highlighting the author's pride in her home state.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
The goal was to determine if growers can maintain soybean productivity and profitability using reduced tillage and cover crops, which protect soil but are often perceived as risky.

The study looked at 4 management systems: conventional tillage (CT), strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR). Each system was paired with 3 starter fertilizer strategies: unfertilized control, 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac.

Key findings:
- Starter fertilizer increased early-season soybean biomass by ~12% but did not significantly impact final yields.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across sites, with no significant differences between tillage systems (CT/ST averaged 78.4 bu/ac, NT 77.6 bu/ac, NT+CR 76.2 bu/ac).
- While yields were similar, reduced tillage systems had higher partial net returns due to lower operational costs.
- The higher costs of the cereal rye cover crop resulted in the lowest partial net returns for NT+CR, though cost-share programs can offset this.

The project will continue in 2026 to track medium-term responses as the soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics change under the conservation systems.

- Average 2024 costs of production were $4.71/bu for corn, $11.02/bu for soybeans, and $6.26/bu for spring wheat, exceeding local cash prices.
- Median net farm income in Minnesota hit a 25-year low of $2,400 in 2024 due to tight profit margins.
- In 2025, the Farmer Bridge Assistance program allocated $11 billion nationally to help cover up to 35% of expected crop losses.
- The 2026 Farm Bill will include changes like raising the annual payment limit to $155,000, increasing ARC/PLC reference prices, and allowing use of Supplemental Coverage Option with ARC.
- U.S. corn production hit a new record in 2025, creating a surplus, but exports are expected to increase to use up the excess supply.

The article provides critical information for Minnesota farmers on costs, profitability, government support programs, and the crop market outlook.

items.title: Announcing the 2026-27 UMN Extension Cover Crop Academy
items.summary:
The program will take a deep dive into cover crops tailored to Minnesota's cropping systems and conditions.

The academy kicks off with in-person meetings at research centers in Lamberton, Waseca, and Westport, Minnesota in June 2026, where participants will visit cover crop research plots and learn about regional successes and challenges. Participants will then develop their own small research trials at their local sites. Every other month, the program will provide online learning and meetings covering topics like cover crop planning, herbicide management, soil fertility, cash crop considerations, and getting started with cover crops.

The academy will wrap up in May 2027 with in-person meetings where participants can assess the results of their local trials. Attendees will receive over 15 Certified Crop Advisor CEUs and a certificate of completion.

The cost to participate is only $100, thanks to support from the Minnesota NRCS, General Mills, and the Minnesota Office of Soil Health. Registration is limited and due by June 5, 2026. All attendees are expected to participate in the full program.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
However, growing in a greenhouse can still be productive. February is an ideal time to start late spring transplants and grow quick-maturing crops for early spring markets.

Greenhouse Basics:
- Greenhouses trap thermal heat to warm plants, with some offering vents, climate controls, and irrigation systems.
- Modular plastic greenhouses can raise temperatures up to 30¬∞F higher. Low tunnels can raise temperatures 2-15¬∞F, while cold frames can raise it 5-15¬∞F.
- Well-designed greenhouses with climate controls allow year-round growing.

What to Grow:
- Tomatoes and peppers benefit from early indoor planting, needing consistent warmth (at least 50¬∞F) to germinate.
- Brassicas like kale, cabbage, and cauliflower can be grown indoors to avoid pests and extreme cold.
- Lettuces, potatoes, onions, and many flowers can also get a head start in the greenhouse.

The article provides guidance on selecting the right greenhouse type based on your climate and growing needs. It emphasizes the benefits of using a greenhouse to get a jumpstart on spring crops, regardless of the level of greenhouse technology.

items.title: Is it cold enough yet? Insect overwintering forecasts for 2026
items.summary:
According to the data, the coldest temperatures reached in January 2026 were around -20¬∞F in the southern and central parts of the state, and below -30¬∞F in the northeast.

For soybean aphids, the article predicts very little mortality (0-50%) in the southern half of the state and the Red River Valley, but 50-95% mortality in north-central and northeast Minnesota. This is an improvement over the extremely mild winter of 2024, but not as favorable as the strong polar vortex in 2019 which caused up to 90% aphid mortality.

For alfalfa weevil, the article states that with soil temperatures only reaching a minimum of 15.4¬∞F at one location, not much mortality is expected this year. Northern areas with less snow cover may see slight reductions in alfalfa weevil pressure.

Corn rootworm forecasting is more complex, as their eggs overwinter in the soil. At the coldest 4 and 8-inch soil temperatures recorded (-19.4¬∞F and -23.0¬∞F), not much acute mortality is expected. Rootworm mortality depends on both temperature and duration of exposure.

Emerald ash borer, while not a field crop pest, was also discussed. The article predicts 25% or more mortality in the northern half of the state after accounting for the insulation provided by ash tree bark.

The article recommends that farmers be proactive about scouting for soybean aphids this year, and consider aphid-resistant soybean varieties if available. No other specific recommendations for farmers are provided.
